text: Theresa May summarises the choice now facing the Commons in a letter to MPs
author: asabenn

text: Matt on indicative Brexit votes
author: asabenn

text: Glad to know the AG is reading
author: asabenn

text: True. Lidington could just be preparing for Letwin3 to force indicative votes onto the agenda
author: asabenn

text: No worries, great to be on - thanks for having me!
author: asabenn

text: Kwarteng indicates Government will hope Bercow will let MV3 happen on basis that "circumstances will have changed. We'll have had eu input in what the timetable is and I think those different circumstances it may well be argued could allow for MV3"
author: asabenn

text: The Banter Heuristic demands no less
author: asabenn

text: Nothing to stop it delaying MV3 that long. Could give May more time to repair relations with MPs...
author: asabenn

text:
Kwarteng tells Benn for making "an assumption about when the meaningful vote may take place" by asking him to back Letwin3 amendment next week.
Suggestion MV3 will be delayed... maybe even  beyond next week?
author: asabenn

text: Indeed. But some still insistent we can have some sort of pseudo no-deal next Friday anyway  (just as credible a belief as idea Orban would veto a delay)
author: asabenn

text: Intrigued by how confident some people are that a House of Commons that voted by a majority of 211 to delay Brexit could throw out a statutory instrument to make UK law reflect the delay EU/May have agreed...
author: asabenn

text: Tempted to ask @oflynnmep to set that out, given his SDP expertise...!
author: asabenn

text: @jameskirkup
author: asabenn

text: Sounds like Macron is worried about UK pursuing the #CrispCompromise @JamesCrisp6
author: asabenn

text:
.@JasonGroves1 asks if UK will "ever be leaving" the EU.
May says: "Yes, we will be leaving the European Union'
author: asabenn

text: May holding door open to softer Brexit if her deal rejected again? Tells @tnewtondunn if MV3 fails "we need to work with the House to decide how to proceed"
author: asabenn

text: "I do not believe we should be revoking Article 50" Theresa May tells reporters
author: asabenn

text: Theresa May trying to repair damage of Wednesday night's telling off of MPs, now saying she understands their frustration and have a "difficult job to do"
author: asabenn

text: Those pointing out exit date still needs to be changed to stop no deal next Friday should bear this in mind
author: asabenn

text: Brexiteers hoping one of EU27 would veto a delay will be disappointed. No deal Brexit won't be happening next Friday then
author: asabenn

text: Calling all flextensioneers, here's who you have to thank for that catching on
author: asabenn

text: An April MV3 gives May another week to inspire MPs with an extra telling-off from her PM podium
author: asabenn

text:
May 7 is a bit less than what @SteveBakerHW and co wanted to make its Malthouse No Deal work. 
Extra time even if deal rejected will delight Brexiteers
Basically, ERG should make Macron an honorary member
author: asabenn

text: ERG shouldn't worry that May plans to take Brexit from them - she is struggling just to get a short delay
author: asabenn

text: "Good news Theresa, we've agreed to extend it to June 30. But it's June 30 2021."
author: asabenn

text: True. Underlines need for proper planning in the event of a no-deal, especially if Tories are to still appeal to nonLeavey sorts
author: asabenn

text: May might keep Tories happy with a no-deal Brexit, but they'll own everything it causes - disruption included - in the public's mind.
author: asabenn

text: As subtweets of Theresa May go, this one is...pierless
author: asabenn

text: "We'd be heading" - ooh that is an even classier translation than what James and I were fumbling towards
author: asabenn

text:
Ah oui. Absolument. Subjunctive = "allions" - doh. Merci mon brave! 
(@AurelieBonal can't accuse us of falling short in our efforts to analyse the significance of what the President says)
author: asabenn

text: Macron said "irions" (subjunctive) - "would go" - not "irons" - "going"! #macronanalysis
author: asabenn

text: Broken the 200 hour mark... (unless EU/UK agree Brextra time)
author: asabenn

text: A long, rather than short one, presumably...
author: asabenn

text: 12,000 times? Not far off how many times the PM has said the UK would be leaving the EU on 29 March 2019...
author: asabenn

text: Think this isn't aging too badly, given current Remainer excitement about their latest #RevokeArticle50 petition
author: asabenn

text: May has managed to unite Brexiteer and Remainer Tories...against her
author: asabenn

text:
Might May threaten another referendum/long delay if Tory MPs don't back her deal?
Might explain why she is dodging 1922: such a threat would make MPs tempted to throw chairs at her
author: asabenn

text: No need for name-calling Misty, just because Allie is trying to play devil's advocate
author: asabenn

text:
True. Trouble is recent polls aren't showing some groundswell of May-deal-mania. 
Maybe she hopes for a revolt in her favour among "bored of Brexit/get on with it" voters?
author: asabenn

text: Bit pointless going over MPs (who have to approve the deal) asking the country to vote it instead...unless there is another referendum coming
author: asabenn

text:
If Theresa May buckles and delays Brexit, I will do my best to tear her party limb from limb - it deserves no better, warns @Nigel_Farage
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/20/theresa-may-buckles-delays-brexit-will-do-best-tear-party-limb/ …
author: asabenn

text: Too busy trying to hammer out Varadkar's contract as a Number 10 press officer
author: asabenn

text: Dublin scoops Downing Street YET AGAIN
author: asabenn

text: Correction: Tusk hasn't undermined May's threat to Eurosceptics outright. Rejecting her deal only kills off "short" extension. Long one could still happen - although May's #pmqs words today would suggest her resignation would have to follow
author: asabenn

text:
Big thing interesting Remainer/Labour MPs is the Kyle amendment - backing the deal as long as there is a referendum. 
That must be what Tusk, who has previously spoken of how he dreams that the UK remains in the EU, is hoping to engineer
author: asabenn

text:
Tusk hardball forcing May to turn attention to Remainers,, with new threat that if they don't back her deal, then UK set for no deal exit
But it destroys her efforts to woo ERG/Tory Brexiteers with threat of "no Brexit" if they fail to back her deal
author: asabenn

text: Are you pulling Adam off the Eurostar?
author: asabenn

text: To be fair, "Parliament vs the people" was the central theme in her speech announcing... the 2017 general election
author: asabenn

text:
#Brexicanstandoff latest:
EU won't decide until May gets deal back to HoC
Bercow won't let it back to HoC without something new from EU
Meanwhile, DUP won't back the deal until remaining Tory Brexiteers do, who won't do it until DUP does, while Labour MPs won't until others do
author: asabenn

text: Clearing the way for Mr Brexit @Nigel_Farage to sweep in as leader
author: asabenn

text: Clearly needed Tim Barrow to get on the Eurostar to hand delive this letter
author: asabenn

text: Bercowtastic anthem for MV3 #Order
author: asabenn

text: Team May denying she is about to get her podium out
author: asabenn

text: Snap election announcement?
author: asabenn

text: If the PM is getting the pedestal out again, will she just give a rehash of her #pmqs remarks - "not prepared" to delay Brexit beyond June 30 etc - or say something surprising?
author: asabenn

text: Instead of going to 1922 Committee?
author: asabenn

text:
Theresa May making a point out of preparation.
PM told MPs today at #pmqs she is "not prepared" to delay Brexit beyond the 30th June
This comes after her spox said yesterday she was "not prepared" to revoke Article 50
author: asabenn

text:
Theresa May: "I'm opposed to a long extension. I don't want a long extension...."
As we know, PM's opposition doesn't strictly stop something happening....
author: asabenn

text: Here's how Theresa May hopes to convince John Bercow/Parliament that her deal is not the same in #MV3 - to get EU leaders to approve the additions she agreed in Strasbourg with Juncker and to offer domestic assurances to DUP/ERG about backstop
author: asabenn

text: Here's the PM's letter to Donald Tusk
author: asabenn

text:
Theresa May: "As Prime Minister, I am not prepared to delay Brexit any further than 30 June" 
#PMQs 
Is the PM suggesting she'd resign if Brexit dragged on any longer?
author: asabenn

text: EU elections "not in anyone's interests" and "unacceptable" for Brexit Britain, says Theresa May at #PMQs
author: asabenn

text: Fitting response: "A wild punt" could describe the Government's first meaningful vote on the Brexit deal...
author: asabenn

text:
#brexicanstandoff
Tory Brexiteers waiting for DUP to get behind Brexit deal before they do
Meanwhile, DUP waiting for enough Tories to move 
And Labour MPs will not risk swinging behind the deal unless they are sure enough will join them to make it pass
Who breaks first?
author: asabenn

text:
Theresa May should have taken @realDonaldTrump's advice on Brexit, writes his son @DonaldJTrumpJr for @Telegraph
https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2019/03/19/donald-trump-junior-says-theresa-may-should-have-taken-his-fathers-brexit-advice/ …
author: asabenn

text:
John Curtice introduced by @BBCSimonMcCoy rightly as "friend of everyone" 
fyi @JohnCurticeOnTV
author: asabenn

text: Hope Cox comes out to boom at them: "What are you doing? What are you playing at? You are not children in a playground!"
author: asabenn

text: Is the DUP trying to consciously uncouple with the ERG?
author: asabenn

text: 30th June... but no specific year?
author: asabenn

text: In 1986, John Bercow also called for the BBC to be privatised: "That fount of cultural snobbery must go"
author: asabenn

text: Hasn't taken long for TIG to radicalise...
author: asabenn

text: Bercow self-owns himself in the same interview with his protestations against "glitz"
author: asabenn

text: The photo accompanying the piece is quite something (interviewed alongside Ruffley)
author: asabenn

text: In 2000, Bercow was on the warpath against rambling MPs. Certainly not one to ever be accused as Speaker of verbosity...
author: asabenn

text: In the same interview, Bercow said female MPs "moaning about sexism" were trying to cover up "their own inadequacy", unlike "competent, attractive ones like Yvette Cooper", and that Labour women lack the "individuality...flair" of "our Ann Widdecombes"
author: asabenn

text: And here's John Bercow boasting to @Telegraph in 1998 about his "licence to interfere" in the Commons
author: asabenn

text: From the @Telegraph archive: John Bercow in 1986 on why you should "mug your opponents" (leaving it unsaid whether that applied to fellow Tories)
author: asabenn

text: #MeaningfulAutocorrect
author: asabenn

text: Isn't the big flaw with a "notwithstanding" ploy that it assumes MPs emphatically want to vote for the deal? MV1/MV2 hardly indicate an overwhelming demand...
author: asabenn

text: How could Bercow resist?
author: asabenn

text: John Bercow sums up today's front pages and headlines
author: asabenn

text: If Theresa May expected sympathy after Bercow stopped her putting the Brexit deal to a third Commons vote, she will not find it on Donald Tusk's Instagram
author: asabenn

text: Indeed. Bercow derailed MV3 but did not derail delaying Brexit in the process...
author: asabenn

text: Me trying to search something I said about past MV. Deleted! hah
author: asabenn

text: True!
author: asabenn

text: Maybe Bercow has decided to help the ERG out, as a former member... ,
author: asabenn

text: John Bercow was a member of the ERG back in his old Monday Club/right-wing Tory backbencher days...
author: asabenn

text: Bercow says Gov 'cannot legitimately do is resubmit to the House the same proposition or substantially the same" as last week's MV2 deal
author: asabenn

text:
Bercow explaining why he did not disallow MV2 because it could be "credibly argued" it was different from deal originally presented 
But MV3 on the other hand...?
author: asabenn

text:
Government would have hoped for MPs to be clamouring for a third vote to help justify it. 
Lack of such a clamour clears way for Bercow to wade in...
author: asabenn

text: Bercow cites concerns from MPs across HoC about #MV3 as he makes his judgement. Not looking good for the Government...
author: asabenn

text: John Bercow preparing for his big statement today like...
author: asabenn

text: Umunna's remarks on @NickBoles make me think he tried to get him to join TIG and was turned down...
author: asabenn

text: Oh I'm not seriously airing a Bercow/JRM switcheroo. But I couldn't resist pondering its appeal to Brexiteers...
author: asabenn

text:
Alternatively, as a leftfield thought, has May managed to persuade Bercow to follow Olly Robbins out the door as an incentive to get Brexiteers to back her deal?

Wonder how some would react if the choice was: May deal with Speaker JRM vs A50 extension and Bercow stays on...
author: asabenn

text: Is he going to make @RhonddaBryant's day by blocking MV3?
author: asabenn

text:
Outrageous. The saga actually goes: 
Meaningful Vote 
Meaningful Vote 2: Judgment Day
Meaningful Vote 3: Rise of the DUP
Meaningful Vote: Salvation
author: asabenn

text: Imagine if May got Brexiteers on side by promising this, only to give him a peerage after getting her deal through so she could bring in "Lord Robbins" as Brexit Secretary
author: asabenn

text: I quit the government over Theresa May's Brexit deal. But I cannot ignore the risks of rejecting her deal again says @willquince
author: asabenn

text: Delaying #MV3 to next week "may be sensible", JRM says
author: asabenn

text: Many ERGers still prefer no deal Brexit to May's deal. But if they conclude HoC/EU will never let no-deal Brexit happen...
author: asabenn

text:
Jacob Rees-Mogg slaps down "wishful thinking" from LBC caller who suggests Italy/Hungary could veto an A50 extension. "They won't," he says.
"There's no hope of us getting a veto...they're not going to spend their political capital in the EU on a country that is about to leave"
author: asabenn

text: Jacob Rees-Mogg tells LBC: "Ultimately, the United Kingdom is more important to me than the European Union... I don't want to see my country chopped up"
author: asabenn

text: If enough Tory MPs/DUP don't indicate they're ready to back the deal, May expected to ask EU leaders for the long two-year delay and then see how MPs feel next week with choice of her deal or Brexit itself kicked into long grass
author: asabenn

text: Theresa May will delay MV3 on Brexit deal if she does not believe she can win it this week, ministers reveal
author: asabenn

text:
Sounds like he's not expecting Poland to answer his request to block an A50 extension...
https://inews.co.uk/news/brexit/daniel-kawczynski-poland-no-deal-brexit-article-50-block-extension/ …
author: asabenn

text: Only if it was 100% of ERG say.  Labour MPs need to feel confident they can risk their careers to help deal through, not just to help it lose by less. So trickle of Brexiteer  support - given 149 majority against to overcome - helps
author: asabenn

text:
Are ERGers thinking what Lord Howard's thinking?
"Not really," one Tory MP tells me. "I don’t think I’m for turning, to borrow a more successful leader's slogan..."
author: asabenn
